title: Cleaning Flatpak and User-Level Bitwarden Remnants After Uninstall
context: After uninstalling Bitwarden on Pop!_OS 24.04, several Flatpak metadata and icon files were found in system and user directories.
keyIdea: Flatpak often leaves small metadata traces after uninstalling apps. These can be safely removed from /var/lib/flatpak and ~/.local/share/flatpak without affecting other applications.
commands:
# Clean dangling Flatpak entries
sudo flatpak uninstall --unused

# Remove app data and overrides
sudo rm -rf /var/lib/flatpak/app/com.bitwarden.desktop
sudo rm -rf /var/lib/flatpak/overrides/com.bitwarden.desktop
sudo rm -rf ~/.local/share/flatpak/app/com.bitwarden.desktop
sudo rm -rf ~/.local/share/flatpak/overrides/com.bitwarden.desktop

# Remove appstream metadata/icons
sudo find /var/lib/flatpak/appstream -iname '*bitwarden*' -exec sudo rm -rf {} +
find ~/.local/share/flatpak/appstream -iname '*bitwarden*' -exec rm -rf {} +

# Securely delete exported vault
shred -u ~/Downloads/bitwarden_export_20251119162149.zip
explanation: Even after uninstalling Flatpak apps, residual metadata, icons, and override files may persist. Cleaning these directories restores a truly clean system state. Sensitive vault exports should be securely shredded.

reusabilityNotes.whenToReuse: Use this process for any Flatpak application with lingering data.
reusabilityNotes.pitfalls: Always confirm filenames before running rm -rf or shred to avoid deleting unrelated files.
